title: Hosea Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 10.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:1, Israel is described as what kind of vine?
options: An empty vine
A fruitful vine
A wild vine
A withered vine
questions.correctAnswer: An empty vine
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:1 states that Israel is an empty vine that brings forth fruit unto himself.

questions.question: What happens to the altars and images according to Hosea 10:2?
options: They shall be broken down and spoiled
They shall be built higher
They shall be blessed
They shall be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be broken down and spoiled
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:2 says the altars shall be broken down and images spoiled because their hearts are divided.

questions.question: Why do they say 'We have no king' in Hosea 10:3?
options: Because they feared not the LORD
Because the king died
Because the land was peaceful
Because the king was strong
questions.correctAnswer: Because they feared not the LORD
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:3 explains that they say 'We have no king' because they did not fear the LORD.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:4, what springs up like hemlock in the furrows of the field?
options: Judgment
Mercy
Peace
Blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:4 states that judgment springeth up as hemlock in the furrows of the field.

questions.question: What shall the inhabitants of Samaria fear because of, as mentioned in Hosea 10:5?
options: The calves of Bethaven
The king of Assyria
The priests of Judah
The high mountains
questions.correctAnswer: The calves of Bethaven
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:5 says the inhabitants of Samaria shall fear because of the calves of Bethaven.

questions.question: To whom shall the calves of Bethaven be carried as a present, according to Hosea 10:6?
options: King Jareb of Assyria
The king of Judah
The priests of Samaria
The children of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: King Jareb of Assyria
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:6 states the calves shall be carried to Assyria as a present to king Jareb.

questions.question: How is the king of Samaria described in Hosea 10:7?
options: Cut off as the foam upon the water
Strong as a lion
Wise as a serpent
Blessed by God
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off as the foam upon the water
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:7 describes the king of Samaria as being cut off like foam on water.

questions.question: What will grow on the high places of Aven according to Hosea 10:8?
options: Thorn and thistle
Flowers and vines
Trees and bushes
Grain and herbs
questions.correctAnswer: Thorn and thistle
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:8 says thorn and thistle shall grow on the high places of Aven.

questions.question: From which location did Israel sin according to Hosea 10:9?
options: Gibeah
Bethlehem
Jericho
Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: Gibeah
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:9 states Israel has sinned from the days of Gibeah.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:12, what should people do to seek the LORD?
options: Sow in righteousness and break up fallow ground
Build more altars
Offer sacrifices daily
Gather large armies
questions.correctAnswer: Sow in righteousness and break up fallow ground
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:12 advises to sow in righteousness and break up fallow ground to seek the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 10:11 compares Ephraim to a heifer that loves to tread out the corn.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:11 describes Ephraim as a heifer that is taught and loves to tread out the corn.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 10:3 says that they say 'We have a king' because they feared the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:3 says they say 'We have no king' because they feared not the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 10:14, a tumult will arise and all fortresses will be spoiled.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:14 predicts a tumult and the spoiling of all fortresses among the people.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Hosea 10:13: 'Ye have plowed _______, ye have reaped iniquity; ye have eaten the fruit of lies.'
options: wickedness
righteousness
peace
mercy
questions.correctAnswer: wickedness
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:13 states, 'Ye have plowed wickedness, ye have reaped iniquity; ye have eaten the fruit of lies.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Hosea 10:15: 'So shall ______ do unto you because of your great wickedness.'
options: Bethel
Samaria
Gibeah
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:15 says, 'So shall Bethel do unto you because of your great wickedness.'

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Hosea 10:12 teach us about the importance of spiritual discipline in seeking God?
options: It encourages us to sow righteousness and break up our fallow ground to seek the LORD
It advises us to rely on our own strength and ignore righteousness
It tells us to wait passively for God to act without effort
It suggests focusing on worldly success as a sign of God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: It encourages us to sow righteousness and break up our fallow ground to seek the LORD
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:12 emphasizes proactive spiritual discipline: sowing righteousness, breaking up fallow ground, and seeking the LORD. This shows the importance of personal devotion and effort in drawing near to God.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with divided loyalty and fear of judgment. Based on Hosea 10:2, what biblical truth would you share?
options: A divided heart leads to being found faulty, but God can break down false altars and images
Divided hearts are acceptable and cause no problem
Fear of judgment means God has abandoned us
One should rely solely on human counsel in times of fear
questions.correctAnswer: A divided heart leads to being found faulty, but God can break down false altars and images
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:2 teaches that a divided heart results in faultiness and judgment, but God will break down altars and spoil images, calling for wholehearted devotion and obedience.

questions.question: How does Hosea 10:11 illustrate the value of obedience and training in the Christian life?
options: Ephraim, like a taught heifer, loves to work under guidance, showing the blessing of obedience
Ephraim refuses to be trained and rejects guidance
Obedience is unnecessary in spiritual growth
Training is only for leaders, not for everyone
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim, like a taught heifer, loves to work under guidance, showing the blessing of obedience
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:11 compares Ephraim to a heifer taught to tread corn, highlighting the blessing of being trained and obedient, which leads to fruitful service and growth in righteousness.

questions.question: What warning does Hosea 10:13 give about trusting in human strength rather than God?
options: Trusting in human strength leads to reaping iniquity and eating the fruit of lies
Human strength is the surest foundation for success
Trusting God is optional when one has mighty men
Relying on many warriors guarantees victory
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in human strength leads to reaping iniquity and eating the fruit of lies
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:13 warns that relying on human power and many mighty men results in wicked outcomes, showing the importance of trusting God instead of self or numbers.

questions.question: How does Hosea 10:15 relate to the consequences of persistent wickedness for leaders and communities?
options: The king of Israel will be cut off because of great wickedness, showing that sin leads to downfall
Wickedness has no real consequence on leadership
Communities thrive despite leaders’ sin
Leaders are always protected regardless of behavior
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Israel will be cut off because of great wickedness, showing that sin leads to downfall
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:15 conveys that persistent wickedness results in severe judgment, including the removal of leaders, emphasizing the need for integrity and repentance.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 10:3 suggests that fearing the LORD protects a nation from lacking a king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:3 states that Israel will say they have no king because they did not fear the LORD, implying that fear of God is foundational to stable leadership.

questions.question: How does Hosea 10:4 warn about the importance of honesty and integrity in making covenants?
options: Swearing falsely in covenants leads to judgment springing up like hemlock
False swearing has no consequences if done for good reasons
One should avoid making any covenants at all
Judgment is unrelated to covenant faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Swearing falsely in covenants leads to judgment springing up like hemlock
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:4 highlights that dishonest words and false oaths cause bitter judgment, emphasizing the biblical call for truthfulness and integrity in all agreements.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on worldly strength rather than God’s guidance. What lesson from Hosea 10:6 would be most helpful?
options: Trusting worldly counsel leads to shame and disgrace
Worldly strength guarantees protection
Shame only comes from enemies, not from bad counsel
It is wise to ignore God’s warnings and rely on human plans
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting worldly counsel leads to shame and disgrace
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:6 shows Ephraim receiving shame and Israel being ashamed of its own counsel, teaching that reliance on worldly strategies apart from God leads to failure.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 10:1 uses the metaphor of an empty vine to describe Israel’s self-centered fruitfulness and idolatry.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:1 describes Israel as an empty vine that produces fruit for itself and increases altars and images, illustrating self-centeredness and idolatry.

questions.question: What practical advice about repentance and seeking God’s mercy can be drawn from Hosea 10:12?
options: It is time to sow righteousness and seek the LORD until He rains righteousness
Repentance is unnecessary if you have done good deeds
Mercy will come regardless of actions
One should wait for God’s mercy passively
questions.correctAnswer: It is time to sow righteousness and seek the LORD until He rains righteousness
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:12 encourages active repentance by sowing righteousness and seeking God, promising that God will respond with mercy and righteousness.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:10, what does God desire regarding discipline and unity among His people?
options: God desires to chastise but also to gather His people united against sin
God wants to abandon His people entirely
Discipline is unnecessary if people are divided
Unity among sinners is not important
questions.correctAnswer: God desires to chastise but also to gather His people united against sin
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:10 shows God’s will to discipline His people and gather them together, binding themselves in unity to face consequences and turn back to Him.

questions.question: How does Hosea 10:8 illustrate the desire for deliverance in times of overwhelming guilt or judgment?
options: People wish the mountains and hills would cover or fall upon them because of sin
They confidently face judgment without fear
They seek to hide behind false idols
They deny their guilt and blame others
questions.correctAnswer: People wish the mountains and hills would cover or fall upon them because of sin
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:8 depicts Israel’s desperate wish to be hidden or destroyed by nature itself due to the weight of their sin and judgment, showing the seriousness of repentance.

questions.question: What lesson about the consequences of sin for families and communities is taught in Hosea 10:14?
options: Sin leads to violent destruction and trauma, as shown by the spoiling of fortresses and the mother dashed upon her children
Sin only affects individuals, not families
Communities remain intact regardless of sin
Judgment is always mild and forgiving
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to violent destruction and trauma, as shown by the spoiling of fortresses and the mother dashed upon her children
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:14 illustrates the harsh consequences of sin affecting entire communities and families, emphasizing the need for repentance and righteous living.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 10:9 says, 'O Israel, thou hast sinned from the days of ______.'
options: Gibeah
Bethaven
Samaria
Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Gibeah
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:9 explicitly states that Israel has sinned from the days of Gibeah, marking a long history of sinfulness.

questions.question: Based on Hosea 10:5, what does the mourning over the calves of Bethaven teach us about the danger of idolatry?
options: Idolatry causes fear and mourning because the glory departs
Idolatry brings lasting joy and blessing
Calves are harmless symbols without spiritual consequence
Worshiping idols ensures protection from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry causes fear and mourning because the glory departs
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:5 shows that the people and priests mourn over the calves of Bethaven because their glory departs, teaching that idolatry leads to loss and fear.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 10.

questions.question: In Hosea 10:1, Israel is compared to what agricultural metaphor, and what does this symbolize about their spiritual state?
options: An empty vine producing fruit for itself
A barren fig tree with no fruit
A flowing river without banks
A withered olive branch
questions.correctAnswer: An empty vine producing fruit for itself
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:1 uses the metaphor of Israel as an 'empty vine' that brings forth fruit unto itself, symbolizing self-serving idolatry and spiritual emptiness despite outward fruitfulness.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'heart is divided' phrase in Hosea 10:2 in relation to Israel's covenant relationship with God?
options: It indicates internal spiritual conflict and unfaithfulness
It refers to political division between tribes
It means they are physically separated geographically
It describes their economic disparity
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates internal spiritual conflict and unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:2 highlights Israel's divided heart which reflects their unfaithfulness and instability in their covenant with God, leading to their coming judgment.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:3, why will Israel say 'We have no king' and how does this reflect their attitude toward God?
options: Because they feared not the LORD, questioning the need for a human king
Because their king was captured by Assyria
Because they desired a foreign ruler instead
Because the monarchy was abolished by priests
questions.correctAnswer: Because they feared not the LORD, questioning the need for a human king
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:3 shows Israel's lack of reverence for God, leading them to dismiss both divine and human authority, reflecting spiritual rebellion.

questions.question: What does the imagery of 'judgment springeth up as hemlock in the furrows of the field' in Hosea 10:4 suggest about the consequences of Israel's false covenants?
options: Judgment will grow quickly and poison their land
Their crops will flourish abundantly
They will find peace and prosperity
Their enemies will flee in fear
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment will grow quickly and poison their land
questions.explanation: The hemlock, a poisonous plant, symbolizes that judgment arising from Israel's false covenants will be harmful and pervasive, as stated in Hosea 10:4.

questions.question: Hosea 10:5 mentions 'the calves of Bethaven.' What is the significance of these calves in the context of Israel's idolatry?
options: They represent idols that cause fear and mourning among Samaria's inhabitants
They are symbols of agricultural fertility
They mark the boundary stones of the land
They are animals sacrificed to Yahweh
questions.correctAnswer: They represent idols that cause fear and mourning among Samaria's inhabitants
questions.explanation: The calves of Bethaven are idols causing distress and mourning, illustrating Israel's idolatry and its consequences according to Hosea 10:5.

questions.question: The gift carried to Assyria in Hosea 10:6 is a symbol of what historical and theological reality for Israel?
options: Their submission and shame before foreign powers
Their military alliance with Assyria
Their economic prosperity
Their religious purification
questions.correctAnswer: Their submission and shame before foreign powers
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:6 depicts Israel's shame as their idolatry leads to subjugation under Assyria, symbolized by sending idols as tribute.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in Hosea 10:7 when describing the king of Samaria as 'cut off as the foam upon the water' and what does it imply?
options: Simile emphasizing transience and instability of the monarchy
Metaphor indicating strength and permanence
Hyperbole showing eternal reign
Alliteration highlighting the king's power
questions.correctAnswer: Simile emphasizing transience and instability of the monarchy
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:7 uses a simile comparing the king’s fate to fleeting foam, underscoring the fragility and sudden end of his rule.

questions.question: In Hosea 10:8, what do the 'thorn and thistle' growing on the altars symbolize in the cultural context of ancient Israel?
options: Desolation and divine judgment upon idolatrous worship sites
Fertile land blessed by God
Places of agricultural prosperity
Gardens cultivated by priests
questions.correctAnswer: Desolation and divine judgment upon idolatrous worship sites
questions.explanation: The growth of thorns and thistles signifies abandoned, cursed idolatrous sites, reflecting judgment in Hosea 10:8.

questions.question: Hosea 10:9 references the 'days of Gibeah.' What historical event or theme does this allusion evoke about Israel’s sinfulness?
options: The civil strife and moral corruption during the time of the Judges
The conquest of Canaan under Joshua
The building of Solomon’s temple
The Babylonian exile
questions.correctAnswer: The civil strife and moral corruption during the time of the Judges
questions.explanation: Gibeah is associated with severe internal sin and conflict, recalling Israel’s longstanding rebellion noted in Hosea 10:9.

questions.question: How does the agricultural imagery in Hosea 10:11, where Ephraim is compared to a heifer, serve to illustrate God's relationship with Israel?
options: It shows God’s training and control over Israel’s productivity
It depicts Israel as wild and untamed
It suggests Israel is free from discipline
It portrays Israel as a destroyer of crops
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God’s training and control over Israel’s productivity
questions.explanation: The metaphor illustrates God's guiding hand teaching Ephraim to work, symbolizing divine discipline in Hosea 10:11.

questions.question: What exhortation is given in Hosea 10:12 regarding righteousness and seeking the LORD, and what agricultural metaphor supports this?
options: Sow righteousness and reap mercy; break up your fallow ground
Harvest wickedness to gain wealth
Ignore the fields and trust in idols
Plant lies and harvest deceit
questions.correctAnswer: Sow righteousness and reap mercy; break up your fallow ground
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:12 uses farming imagery to urge repentance and active seeking of God for blessing and renewal.

questions.question: In Hosea 10:13, what is the consequence of 'plowing wickedness' and 'reaping iniquity' in the context of Israel's covenant infidelity?
options: They eat the fruit of lies and face ruin
They gain wealth and power
They receive divine favor
They build strong fortresses
questions.correctAnswer: They eat the fruit of lies and face ruin
questions.explanation: The verse warns that sinful actions produce destructive results, showing that Israel’s trust in might leads to deception and downfall.

questions.question: The violent imagery in Hosea 10:14, including the dashing of the mother upon her children, alludes to which historical event and what does it signify?
options: The brutal conquest by Shalman, signifying total destruction
The Exodus from Egypt, symbolizing salvation
The building of Jericho’s walls, indicating protection
The coronation of the king, representing peace
questions.correctAnswer: The brutal conquest by Shalman, signifying total destruction
questions.explanation: This allusion to Shalman's massacre illustrates the severe judgment and devastation that awaits Israel for their sins.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:15, what fate awaits Bethel and the king of Israel because of their wickedness?
options: Bethel will do harm and the king will be utterly cut off
Bethel will prosper and the king will reign long
They will be forgiven and restored
They will form new covenants with neighboring nations
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel will do harm and the king will be utterly cut off
questions.explanation: The verse foreshadows destruction upon Israel’s religious center and monarchy due to their great wickedness.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 10:10 indicates that God's desire is to chastise Israel and that they will face collective punishment when bound in their 'two furrows.'
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:10 explicitly states God's intention to chastise Israel, symbolized by the people being gathered and bound in their two furrows, indicating collective judgment.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does God compare Israel to in Hosea 10:1, illustrating their fruitfulness for themselves rather than for God?
options: An empty vine
A fruitful olive tree
A mighty cedar
A blossoming fig tree
questions.correctAnswer: An empty vine
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:1 describes Israel as an empty vine that brings forth fruit unto itself, symbolizing unfaithfulness and self-centered fruitfulness. This metaphor aligns with Isaiah 5:1-7 where Israel is also portrayed as a vineyard producing wild grapes, and with John 15:1-6 where Jesus contrasts the true vine with unfruitful branches.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:2, what consequence follows from Israel’s divided heart?
options: Their altars will be broken down
They will prosper and multiply
God will bless their sacrifices
Their enemies will flee
questions.correctAnswer: Their altars will be broken down
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:2 states that because Israel's heart is divided, they will be found faulty and their altars and images will be destroyed. This reflects the biblical principle that divided loyalty leads to judgment, similar to 1 Kings 18:21 and James 4:8 which call for undivided devotion to God.

questions.question: In Hosea 10:3, why do the people say, 'We have no king'?
options: Because they feared not the LORD
Because their king was righteous
Because they trusted in God alone
Because they wanted a new king
questions.correctAnswer: Because they feared not the LORD
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:3 reveals that the people declare having no king due to their failure to fear the LORD, implying that God's kingship was rejected. This theme parallels 1 Samuel 8:7 where rejecting God as king leads to human kingship, and Romans 13:1 which teaches submission to God-ordained authorities.

questions.question: What does Hosea 10:4 liken the judgment resulting from false covenants to?
options: Hemlock in the furrows of the field
A burning fire in the forest
A storm that uproots trees
A flood that destroys the land
questions.correctAnswer: Hemlock in the furrows of the field
questions.explanation: The judgment from false covenants is compared to hemlock, a poisonous plant, growing among crops, symbolizing harmful consequences arising from unfaithfulness (Hosea 10:4). This imagery aligns with Proverbs 4:17 on the path of the wicked and Galatians 6:7 regarding sowing and reaping.

questions.question: Who will fear because of the calves of Bethaven according to Hosea 10:5?
options: The inhabitants of Samaria
The priests of Jerusalem
The people of Judah
The kings of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: The inhabitants of Samaria
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:5 states that the inhabitants of Samaria will fear because of the calves of Bethaven, reflecting their idolatry and impending judgment. This reflects the recurring condemnation of idol worship seen in Exodus 32 and Romans 1:22-25.

questions.question: What is the significance of the gift sent to Assyria in Hosea 10:6?
options: It symbolizes Israel’s shame and submission
It represents God's blessing on Israel
It marks a new alliance with Egypt
It celebrates Israel's military victory
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Israel’s shame and submission
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:6 describes a gift sent to Assyria as a symbol of Ephraim's shame and Israel's failed counsel, indicating political humiliation. This foreshadows the consequences of trusting in foreign alliances rather than God (Psalm 20:7, Isaiah 31:1).

questions.question: What happened to the king of Samaria as described in Hosea 10:7?
options: He was cut off like foam upon the water
He was exalted above all nations
He led his people to repentance
He established peace with Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He was cut off like foam upon the water
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:7 uses the imagery of foam on water to describe the king's swift and insubstantial end, emphasizing the fleeting nature of human power. This metaphor echoes Psalm 39:6 and James 4:14 about the transience of life and earthly authority.

questions.question: What is described as covering the high places of Aven in Hosea 10:8?
options: Thorn and thistle
Gold and silver
Fine linen and spices
Fire and brimstone
questions.correctAnswer: Thorn and thistle
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:8 says that thorns and thistles will grow over the high places of Aven, symbolizing desolation due to Israel's sin. This imagery is consistent with Isaiah 34:13 and Hebrews 6:8 describing cursed land producing thorns and thistles.

questions.question: What old sin does Hosea 10:9 remind Israel of?
options: Sinning from the days of Gibeah
Idolatry in Egypt
Rebellion at Mount Sinai
Neglecting the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Sinning from the days of Gibeah
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:9 recalls Israel's longstanding sin from Gibeah, referring to their persistent iniquity and civil strife (Judges 19-21). This recalls the biblical theme that unrepented sin leads to downfall, as seen in 1 Kings 21 and Romans 1:18-32.

questions.question: According to Hosea 10:10, what is God's desire concerning Israel?
options: To chastise them and gather people against them
To bless them with peace and prosperity
To establish a new covenant with them
To deliver them from their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: To chastise them and gather people against them
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:10 reveals God's righteous desire to discipline Israel through chastisement and gathering enemies as a consequence of their sin, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:35 and Hebrews 12:6 where God disciplines His people for their good.

questions.question: In Hosea 10:11, what agricultural metaphor describes Ephraim’s character?
options: An heifer that loves to tread out the corn
A vineyard producing wild grapes
A shepherd tending the flock
A lion stalking its prey
questions.correctAnswer: An heifer that loves to tread out the corn
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:11 uses the metaphor of an obedient heifer trained to tread corn to describe Ephraim’s readiness, but God’s sovereignty is emphasized as He makes Ephraim ride. This illustrates submission and God's control, similar to Isaiah 5:7 and Psalm 32:8.

questions.question: What exhortation is given in Hosea 10:12 regarding righteousness?
options: Sow in righteousness, reap in mercy
Build more altars and make sacrifices
Trust in your own strength and wisdom
Seek alliances with foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Sow in righteousness, reap in mercy
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:12 calls Israel to sow righteousness and reap mercy, urging repentance and seeking the LORD, aligning with biblical themes in Galatians 6:7-9 and 2 Chronicles 7:14 regarding righteous living and God’s mercy.

questions.question: What is the consequence of plowing wickedness as stated in Hosea 10:13?
options: Reaping iniquity and eating the fruit of lies
Receiving abundant blessings
Being exalted among nations
Gaining peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Reaping iniquity and eating the fruit of lies
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:13 teaches that sowing wickedness leads to reaping iniquity and consuming lies, emphasizing the law of sowing and reaping found in Proverbs 22:8 and Galatians 6:7, warning against trusting in human strength.

questions.question: What historical event is referenced in Hosea 10:14 to illustrate the coming judgment?
options: Shalman spoiling Betharbel in the day of battle
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The exile to Babylon
The plagues of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Shalman spoiling Betharbel in the day of battle
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:14 refers to the brutal conquest by Shalman (likely Shalmaneser) at Betharbel, illustrating violent judgment. This historical reference underscores the certainty of divine judgment, consistent with 2 Kings 17 and Jeremiah 25:9.

questions.question: What fate does Hosea 10:15 predict for Bethel because of Israel’s wickedness?
options: The king of Israel will be cut off in a morning
It will be exalted as a holy city
It will be restored and blessed
It will become a place of peace
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Israel will be cut off in a morning
questions.explanation: Hosea 10:15 prophesies that Bethel will suffer judgment resulting in the swift removal of Israel’s king, highlighting the consequences of persistent wickedness. This connects with 1 Kings 12:29 and Amos 5:5 about the downfall of places of idolatry.
